repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Spargel Production Rosie the Riveter Media Collection

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in two manuscript boxes and one record carton

did.abstract: This collection consists of interviews of women who entered the industrial workforce (automobiles, shipbuilding, aircraft manufacturing, electrical equipment manufacturing, and transportation) during the years of World War II (1939-1945). Interviews we were created on digital video for use in the Spargel Productions new media project "The Girl With The Rivet Gun." Topics covered include gender relations and discrimination at work, union experience, industrial work, family roles, transitioning from rural to urban environments, race relations, and post-war employment experiences. Transcripts are available for all interviews.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Rosie the Riveter film project was conducted in conjunction with Spargel Productions, LLC and the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives beginning in 2010. The accession number associated with this collection is 2010.014.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Because of the assembled nature of this collection, copyright status varies across the collection. Copyright is assumed to be held by the original creator of individual items in the collection; these items are expected to pass into the public domain 120 years after their creation. Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from repository. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to audiovisual materials in this collection is available through access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Spargel Production Rosie the Riveter Media Collection; OH 081; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Decisions regarding arrangement, description, and physical interventions for this collection prior to 2019 have not yet been recorded.

In 2019 the DVDs were forensically imaged, analyzed, and arranged using Research Workspace. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.
In 2023 digital objects were removed from this collection as the disc images made in 2019 were images of access copies, not originals.
In 2024, individual listings for original recording, transcript, and access copy were added to each interview subject in the inventory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of thirty-three interviews with women who entered the industrial workforce (automobiles, shipbuilding, aircraft manufacturing, electrical equipment manufacturing, and transportation) during the years of World War II (1939-1945). Topics covered include gender relations and discrimination at work, union experience, industrial work, family roles, transitioning from rural to urban environments, education, race relations, and post-war employment experiences. Transcripts are available for all interviews.

bioghist.head: Historical
bioghist.p: These interviews were recorded as a part of a collaborative media project by Spargel Productions and New York University's Tamiment Library. These oral histories were created on digital video and portions of them are used in the Spargel Production new media project "The Girl With The Rivet Gun." They are being preserved at the Tamiment Library.
